claim: The 2007 Toronto International Film Festival featured The Tracey Fragments.

supporting.text: The Tracey Fragments was listed in TIFF's official 2007 program guide under the 'Contemporary World Cinema' section.

attacks.text: The Tracey Fragments was listed in TIFF's official 2007 program guide under the 'Contemporary World Cinema' section.
The official program guide may contain errors or inaccuracies due to last-minute changes.
Listing in a program guide does not guarantee a film's inclusion in the festival lineup.
The 'Contemporary World Cinema' section might not have been an official category at TIFF in 2007.
TIFF's program guides are typically verified by festival organizers and undergo editorial review.
Program guides serve as definitive records of festival lineups and are not subject to last-minute changes.
Historical documentation confirms that 'Contemporary World Cinema' was an official section at TIFF in 2007.
Editorial review processes for TIFF guides do not eliminate all potential errors entirely.
Last-minute changes to festival lineups are common and could invalidate program guide listings.
The term 'Contemporary World Cinema' may have been used informally or misapplied in 2007.

supporting.text: Critic reviews from 2007 explicitly mention the film's premiere at TIFF, noting its inclusion in the festival's lineup.

attacks.text: Critic reviews from 2007 explicitly mention the film's premiere at TIFF, noting its inclusion in the festival's lineup.
The critic reviews cited may have been misinterpreted or misattributed to the wrong festival year.
Premiering at TIFF does not guarantee a film was officially featured in its lineup.
The term 'premiere' in critic reviews could refer to a different event unrelated to TIFF.
Reputable film critics consistently verified the 2007 TIFF lineup through archival records.
TIFF's official documentation confirms that premieres are explicitly listed in their festival programs.
The film's premiere date aligns with TIFF's confirmed schedule for 2007.
Archival records of critic publications show no evidence of misattribution to festival years.
TIFF's historical program archives explicitly list The Tracey Fragments as a premiere entry.
Independent film databases corroborate The Tracey Fragments' premiere at TIFF in 2007.

supporting.text: The film's director, Bruce McDonald, confirmed in interviews that it was screened at TIFF 2007 as part of his career highlights.

attacks.text: The film's director, Bruce McDonald, confirmed in interviews that it was screened at TIFF 2007 as part of his career highlights.
Bruce McDonald's interviews about TIFF 2007 lack corroborating evidence from credible third-party sources.
The absence of an official TIFF 2007 program listing for *The Tracey Fragments* suggests it was not screened there.
Bruce McDonald may conflate TIFF appearances with other film festivals due to memory lapses.
Interviews with directors are considered valid primary sources in film scholarship and festival documentation.
Lack of an official program listing does not disprove a screening; some films may be added informally.
Directors typically maintain accurate records of their work’s festival history unless explicitly contradicted.
Primary sources like interviews are prone to bias or inaccuracies without external verification.
Informal screenings at TIFF require explicit documentation to be considered factual claims.
Directors’ personal recollections may conflict with historical records or logistical data.

supporting.text: TIFF's archives show no record of The Tracey Fragments being featured in their 2007 festival database or historical listings.

attacks.text: TIFF's archives show no record of The Tracey Fragments being featured in their 2007 festival database or historical listings.
TIFF's archives may be incomplete due to data loss or formatting issues prior to 2010.
The absence of a record in TIFF's database does not prove the film was not featured at the festival.
Independent film databases and press coverage from 2007 confirm The Tracey Fragments was screened at TIFF.
Data loss claims lack specific evidence about TIFF's 2007 archive integrity.
Festival databases often exclude non-official screenings or special events from their public records.
Press coverage from 2007 may rely on unverified rumors or promotional materials rather than official listings.
TIFF's archival practices prior to 2010 were standardized and documented in internal audits.
Non-official screenings would still require submission through TIFF's formal selection process.
Reputable film databases like IMDb cross-reference multiple sources beyond single festival claims.

supporting.text: The film was released in Canada in December 2007, after TIFF's September event, making its inclusion implausible.

attacks.text: The film was released in Canada in December 2007, after TIFF's September event, making its inclusion implausible.
The film may have been screened at TIFF as an early preview or special showcase prior to its official Canadian release.
The December 2007 release date cited in A5 may refer to a limited theatrical run rather than an official premiere.
TIFF often features films that have not yet received Canadian distribution licenses or public releases.
Early previews at TIFF typically require prior distribution agreements not confirmed in available records.
The December release date aligns with industry standards for Canadian film rollouts post-festival.
TIFF's programming guidelines prioritize films with theatrical distribution plans rather than unlicensed screenings.

supporting.text: A comprehensive list of films shown at TIFF 2007 by The Globe and Mail does not include The Tracey Fragments.

attacks.text: A comprehensive list of films shown at TIFF 2007 by The Globe and Mail does not include The Tracey Fragments.
The Globe and Mail's list may not account for independent screenings or lesser-known films outside mainstream coverage.
The absence of The Tracey Fragments from one source does not disprove its inclusion in other festival records.
TIFF 2007 officially confirmed The Tracey Fragments was screened through archived program listings accessible online.
Other reputable film databases such as IMDb and Variety explicitly list The Tracey Fragments at TIFF 2007.
The official TIFF program listings cited by C1 lack verifiable timestamps or direct links to proof.
IMDb data relies on user submissions which may contain inaccuracies about festival premieres.
